Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Primary Sjögren's syndrome with systemic involvement
Schizophrenia (with secondary hematologic abnormalities due to medication)
Tuberculosis (with secondary renal and psychiatric manifestations)
Schizophrenia (in the context of multi-system disease)
Hepatitis B or C with kidney involvement
Infectious diseases (e.g., viral or bacterial infections leading to acute pericarditis and potentially affecting the kidneys, manifesting as proteinuria, and causing systemic symptoms like delirium)
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, which can cause pericarditis, kidney damage leading to proteinuria, and central nervous system involvement resulting in delirium)
Uremia (from acute or chronic kidney failure, which could result in proteinuria, with uremic toxins potentially causing pericarditis and delirium)
Malignancies (e.g., cancers that indirectly affect the heart, kidneys, and brain through paraneoplastic syndromes or direct involvement)

Endocarditis (an infection of the heart's inner lining, which could cause acute pericarditis, may be associated with renal involvement like proteinuria, and can lead to delirium due to systemic infection or embolic phenomena)
Drug-induced conditions (certain medications or drugs can cause acute pericarditis, induce kidney damage leading to proteinuria, and lead to acute changes in mental status or delirium)
Toxic exposures (e.g., exposure to toxins that concurrently affect the heart, kidneys, and brain)
Metabolic disorders (e.g., severe hypercalcemia or uremia, potentially causing all three symptoms: delirium, acute pericarditis, and proteinuria)

Vasculitis (inflammatory diseases of the blood vessels, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which might lead to kidney damage and proteinuria, cause pericardial disease, and result in neurological manifestations including delirium)

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS), conditions that could potentially affect the kidneys (proteinuria), heart (pericarditis), and brain (delirium) through microangiopathic mechanisms
Psychiatric Disorders (e.g., Schizophrenia in the Case of Psychosis)
Substance-Induced Delirium (e.g., Alcohol or Drug Abuse)
Schizophrenia (in rare cases with severe systemic involvement)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can explain synovitis, acute pericarditis, seizures due to CNS involvement, and proteinuria as a result of lupus nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While more commonly associated with synovitis, rheumatoid arthritis can sometimes lead to the development of pericarditis and atrophic scarring. However, seizures and proteinuria are not commonly direct manifestations of this condition.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can include symptoms such as synovitis, lung scarring, pericarditis, neurological manifestations including seizures, and kidney involvement potentially presenting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can cause atrophic scarring, and in more severe cases affect internal organs leading to proteinuria due to kidney damage, and pericarditis. Seizures and synovitis are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition primarily increases the risk of blood clots, but it can be associated with lupus. It could indirectly cause seizures through cerebral vascular events, proteinuria through kidney involvement, and rarely, it can be associated with heart and lung issues.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affecting salivary and lacrimal glands, Sjogren's can also lead to joint symptoms and kidney disease (proteinuria). Seizures and pericarditis are less commonly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease can produce a wide range of symptoms including skin scarring and arthritis, but it's less commonly associated with pericarditis, seizures, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Several forms of vasculitis can present with kidney involvement (proteinuria), and possibly seizures and pericarditis, depending on the type and severity. Atrophic scarring and synovitis can occur as a result of the disease or its complications.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition primarily affects the skin and muscles but can occasionally cause complications that mimic or lead to some of the symptoms listed, including atrophic scarring and, rarely, kidney involvement (proteinuria). Pericarditis and seizures are possible but less common.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily an infection of the heart valves, it can cause a wide range of symptoms due to embolic phenomena, including skin manifestations (like atrophic scarring), renal impairment (proteinuria), and possibly seizures. Pericarditis is less commonly directly associated but can occur as a complication.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect the nervous system, potentially leading to seizures and delirium. It can also cause autoimmune hemolysis, pleural effusion, and leukopenia as part of its wide range of hematological and serosal manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This disorder is often associated with systemic autoimmune conditions, particularly lupus, and can lead to blood clots and seizures. It may indirectly or directly contribute to hemolytic anemia, pleural effusions, and leukopenia through immune dysregulation and its impact on the bone marrow.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, sometimes accompanied by leukopenia. Neurological manifestations might not be directly symptomatic but can occur due to the underlying autoimmune activity or treatment side effects.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, it can have systemic manifestations including serositis (which can lead to pleural effusions), leukopenia due to marrow suppression, and autoimmune hemolysis. Neurological complications leading to seizures or delirium are rare but possible.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Although mainly affecting the lungs and lymph glands, sarcoidosis can involve the central nervous system (leading to seizures), cause autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and pleural effusion. Leukopenia could also be part of the hematological abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Various forms of vasculitis can cause systemic issues including delirium and seizures due to CNS involvement, autoimmune hemolysis, pleural effusion from lung involvement, and leukopenia as a result of bone marrow suppression or autoimmune destruction.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can cause autoimmune hemolysis, seizures (if the CNS is involved), pleural effusion (through lymphatic obstruction or infiltration), and leukopenia as a result of bone marrow infiltration.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Some medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome, leading to symptoms such as pleural effusion, leukopenia, and autoimmune hemolysis. CNS involvement is less common but can manifest as seizures or delirium.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.rationale: A rare, acquired, life-threatent disorder that can show a broad range of symptoms due to the destruction of red blood cells, including hemolytic anemia. Although seizures and delirium are uncommon, they can occur due to severe anemia or thromboses. PNH might indirectly cause pleural effusion and leukopenia through its complex pathophysiology.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD combines features of systemic sclerosis, SLE, and polymyositis. It can cause a wide array of symptoms including those affecting the nervous system (seizures, delirium), pleural effusions, autoimmune hemolysis, and leukopenia.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, autoimmune skin condition that speeds up the growth cycle of skin cells, causing raised, red, scaly patches to appear on the skin. Psoriasis can cause onychodystrophy and has been associated with conditions that may present with migratory edema.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it. The rash isn't contagious or life-threatening but can be very uncomfortable. Many substances can cause such reactions, including soaps, cosmetics, fragrances, jewelry and plants.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems, including your joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). It most commonly affects the knees, ankles, and feet, causing pain and swelling. Skin conditions such as psoriasis can also occur in some individuals.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme
diagnoses.description: A skin reaction that can be triggered by an infection or medication. It's characterized by the sudden appearance of red, target-shaped patches or sores on the skin, primarily on the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of rare diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can cause skin changes, including thickening and potential disturbances similar to onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. The rash often precedes muscle weakness and may involve aspects of onychodystrophy and physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. The ovaries may develop numerous small collections of fluid (follicles) and fail to regularly release eggs.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus. Endometriosis can cause pain — sometimes severe — especially during menstrual periods. While it’s listed here due to its inclusion in the symptoms, it would be considered alongside, rather than causing, the other symptoms.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and dry mouth, which can correlate with periodontal disease due to reduced saliva production. It might also be associated with more systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It is characterized by hypermobility. Some types may be associated with dental issues due to connective tissue involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While not directly accounting for all symptoms, its systemic nature can lead to a wide range of manifestations, including periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Some patients report symptoms similar to those described, though not typically the primary presentation.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including neurological issues (potentially affecting hearing), joint pain, and more.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: While primarily known for causing heartburn, GERD can also lead to symptoms such as laryngitis due to acid reflux damaging the throat.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. Some reports suggest a link with immune dysfunction, which could indirectly relate to some of the listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Menière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. Tinnitus is a common symptom. While Menière's disease doesn't account for all the symptoms listed, it's noteworthy for its impact on hearing.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms are highly variable and can include fatigue, mobility issues, and more, possibly including those listed, albeit indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Specific deficits, such as in B vitamins or vitamin D, can affect various bodily functions, potentially leading to a broad range of symptoms, including those affecting dental health, energy levels, and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and can cause systemic complications which may affect concentration and potentially lead to neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, causing telangiectasias, the nervous system, potentially impacting concentration, and can also contribute indirectly to cardiovascular issues.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also have systemic effects including Sjögren’s syndrome (which can lead to dry eyes), and cardiovascular complications, though takotsubo cardiomyopathy is rare.

diagnoses.name: Stress/Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: Though takotsubo cardiomyopathy is referenced specifically, stress cardiomyopathy can be a related or contributing factor, influenced by psychological stress possibly linked with difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder that can lead to an increased risk of vascular complications like telangiectasias and also has been associated with fatigue which might impair concentration.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.description: A skin condition that primarily affects the face and can cause telangiectasias. Rosacea is not directly linked with takotsubo cardiomyopathy, dry eyes, or difficulty concentrating but can coexist with ocular rosacea, leading to dry eyes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Patients often report difficulty concentrating and can have coexisting conditions that affect the eyes and skin.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels including telangiectasias. The condition primarily affects the skin and mucous membranes but can have systemic implications.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including difficulty concentrating. While not directly causing dry eyes or cardiomyopathy, it can be a comorbid condition affecting overall health.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease of the liver that can lead to symptoms associated with Sjögren’s syndrome, such as dry eyes. Though not commonly linked with telangiectasias or takotsubo cardiomyopathy directly, it can contribute to systemic symptoms affecting concentration.

diagnoses: Secondary Hypertension due to Endocrine Disorders

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and presents with symptoms such as telangiectasias and recurrent nosebleeds.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Disease
diagnoses.description: Another name for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia, emphasizing its genetic aspect and the typical manifestations including telangiectasias and arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by excessive mast cell activation, which can lead to symptoms including blood pressure lability, angioedema, and skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by episodes of severe hypotension, hemoconcentration, and generalized edema, possibly related to angioedema and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Carney Complex
diagnoses.description: A genetic syndrome that may present with spotty skin pigmentation, endocrine overactivity, and a variety of heart, skin, and other tumors. It sometimes includes features like blood pressure lability due to adrenal adenomas.

diagnoses.name: C1 Inhibitor Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition that can either be hereditary or acquired, leading to recurrent attacks of angioedema due to the deficiency of the C1 inhibitor protein.

diagnoses.name: Glucagonoma
diagnoses.description: A rare type of tumor of the pancreas that produces excess glucagon, and can be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes mellitus, and weight loss, but might indirectly cause telangiectasias through skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that mainly affects the body's moist tissues and glands causing dry eyes and mouth, but can also cause systemic symptoms, including sinusitis.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener's)
diagnoses.description: A form of vasculitis that can affect the sinuses, lungs, and kidneys, but rarely presents with telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: While primarily causing symptoms of sinusitis and nasal congestion, it can sometimes be associated with broader symptoms like angioedema, especially if there is a cross-reaction or coexisting condition.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Viral infections can lead to laryngitis and bronchitis due to inflammation of the respective tissues. While not directly causing vaginitis, osteopenia, or hemorrhoids, systemic viral effects or related immune responses could exacerbate these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain bacterial infections could lead to bronchitis and laryngitis. Secondary infections or imbalances in normal flora might lead to vaginitis. While less directly related, chronic or systemic bacterial infections could contribute to conditions like osteopenia due to inflammation or nutrient malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Allergies
diagnoses.reasoning: Allergic reactions can cause inflammation of the airways, leading to symptoms of laryngitis and bronchitis. While allergies do not directly cause vaginitis, osteopenia, or hemorrhoids, the inflammation and immune response they trigger can exacerbate these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune diseases, such as Sjögren's Syndrome or lupus, can lead to systemic symptoms affecting various parts of the body, including laryngitis and bronchitis due to dryness or inflammation of the respiratory tract. These diseases can also impact bone density, potentially leading to osteopenia, and could indirectly affect the severity of conditions like vaginitis and hemorrhoids due to overall health and immune function.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress or Fatigue
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic stress and fatigue can weaken the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections that could cause laryngitis and bronchitis. Prolonged stress can also affect hormones and mediate inflammatory responses, potentially exacerbating conditions like vaginitis, osteopenia, and hemorrhoids.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reasoning: GERD can lead to chronic laryngitis due to the irritation of laryngeal tissues by stomach acid. While not directly causing the other conditions, the chronic inflammation associated with GERD could worsen systemic health, potentially influencing osteopenia, vaginitis, and hemorrhoids.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalances
diagnoses.reasoning: Imbalances in hormones, especially estrogen and progesterone, can lead to reproductive health issues like vaginitis, and also affect bone density, contributing to osteopenia. Hormonal shifts might not directly cause laryngitis or bronchitis, but can affect immune function, potentially influencing susceptibility to these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract, IBS can have systemic effects due to inflammation, stress, and dietary restrictions. It's a stretch, but chronic inflammation and stress associated with IBS could potentially aggravate conditions like hemorrhoids (due to gastrointestinal strain), vaginitis (through stress and hormonal fluctuations), osteopenia (through nutrient malabsorption), and even respiratory conditions in a roundabout way via overall health degradation.

diagnoses.name: Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain STIs can cause vaginitis as a primary symptom. While STIs would not be a direct cause of laryngitis, bronchitis, osteopenia, or hemorrhoids, the overall impact on the immune system could make individuals more susceptible to these conditions, or exacerbate existing symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.reasoning: Deficiencies in vitamins and minerals can compromise immune function and tissue health, potentially leading to or exacerbating conditions like bronchitis and laryngitis due to weakened immune defenses. Nutritional deficiencies can directly lead to osteopenia due to lack of necessary bone-building nutrients and indirectly affect conditions like vaginitis and hemorrhoids through overall diminished health.

diagnoses: Cancer (specific types associated with memory problems, ulcers, and decreased appetite, e.g., lung cancer, gastric cancer)
Diabetes (especially with complications leading to infections)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (or other autoimmune diseases with lung involvement)
Dementia (or other neurodegenerative disorders, indirectly causing other symptoms)
Malnutrition (due to decreased appetite, leading to susceptibility to infection)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: A common allergic condition that mimics cold-like symptoms, such as a runny nose and sneezing. It can also affect the eyes and can cause throat irritation.

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as the common cold, it can cause laryngitis, irritated eyes, and can contribute to general malaise, potentially indirectly affecting menstrual cycles due to stress or systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: Though characterized by episodes of breathing difficulty, some patients have normal pulmonary function tests when not experiencing an asthma attack. It can cause laryngitis due to coughing and throat irritation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. It can cause dyspnea, difficulty focusing vision, and exacerbate symptoms like dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the glands that produce moisture in the body. It primarily causes dry eyes and mouth but can also lead to systemic complications including joint pain, and it may indirectly cause symptoms like dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Airway Disease
diagnoses.description: A term sometimes used to describe a condition that mimics asthma, involving hyperreactivity of the bronchial tubes to various stimuli. It can lead to dyspnea and may cause or exacerbate laryngitis but typically shows normal pulmonary function tests when symptoms are not flaring.

diagnoses.name: Environmental Allergies
diagnoses.description: Sensitivity to environmental triggers like pollen, dust, or animal dander. Symptoms can include irritated eyes, laryngitis due to post-nasal drip, and occasionally, difficulty breathing.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid irritates the esophagus, which can lead to or exacerbate laryngitis and cause dyspnea. It can also affect sleep, which might indirectly affect focus and perhaps menstrual cycle.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the body's tissues, causing fatigue, difficulty focusing, and can exacerbate dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalances
diagnoses.description: Conditions like thyroid disorders or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dysmenorrhea, difficulty focusing, and could potentially contribute to respiratory symptoms through systemic inflammation or changes in immune response.

diagnoses: Oral Leukoplakia related to HPV Infection
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Mouth or Throat
Cognitive impairment or stress-related cognitive dysfunction
Electrolyte imbalance secondary to dehydration or bleeding

diagnoses.reasoning: Presents with hyperglycemia, and can have associated complications such as mood lability, increased susceptibility to infections leading to conditions like pneumonia and otitis externa, and can affect wound healing causing easy bleeding.

Certain autoimmune conditions can contribute to hyperglycemia (such as in type 1 diabetes), influence mood lability, increase the risk of infections like pneumonia and otitis externa, and impair coagulation, leading to easy bleeding.

Can lead to coagulopathy (easy bleeding), affect glucose metabolism (contributing to hyperglycemia), alter mental status (mood lability), and impact immune function, increasing susceptibility to infections like pneumonia.

Kidney dysfunction can lead to a range of symptoms due to the accumulation of toxins and altered hormone metabolism. It can indirectly influence glucose control, impact mental health, and alter immune response.

Compromises the immune system, increasing risk of pneumonia and other infections. It can also affect other organ systems potentially leading to mood lability and may have implications for glucose metabolism.

A bleeding disorder that would directly explain the easy bleeding and could complicate other conditions, although it does not directly connect to pneumonia, hyperglycemia, or mood lability without considering co-occurring conditions.

Certain cancers can contribute to the cluster of symptoms through various mechanisms, including impacting immune function, altering metabolism (including glucose metabolism), and affecting mood through both direct and indirect pathways.

Primary or secondary immunodeficiencies increase the risk for infections like pneumonia and otitis externa, and can have overlapping presentations with systemic symptoms affecting multiple organ systems.
While primarily linked to mood lability, severe psychiatric disorders can indirectly affect physical health, including susceptibility to infections and perhaps poorly managed diabetes if present.

Substance use can exacerbate or lead to the development of a wide range of health issues, including infections due to altered immune status, mood disturbances, glucose metabolism disorders, and increased bleeding risk depending on the substance used.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems and can decrease a person’s ability to function at work and at home.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear. Anxiety is a worry about future events, and fear is a reaction to current events. These feelings may cause physical symptoms, such as a fast heart rate and shakiness.

diagnoses.name: End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD)
diagnoses.description: The final stage of chronic kidney disease. This is when your kidneys can no longer support your body's needs. ESRD can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fluid retention, swelling, and decreased cognitive function.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Glucose is vital to your health because it's an important source of energy for the cells that make up your muscles and tissues. It's also your brain's main source of fuel.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both. IBS is a chronic condition that you'll need to manage long term.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Over time, this reaction damages your small intestine's lining and prevents absorption of some nutrients (malabsorption).

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Dysmotility
diagnoses.description: A condition where the stomach takes too long to empty its contents. It often leads to symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, bloating, and an inability to eat a normal size meal.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your immune system mistakenly attacks your body. There are many different types of autoimmune diseases, and they can affect many parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder associated with episodes of mood swings ranging from depressive lows to manic highs. The exact cause of bipolar disorder isn't known, but a combination of genetics, environment, and altered brain structure and chemistry may play a role.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental disorder characterized by at least two weeks of pervasive sadness, loss of interest in activities, and other cognitive and physical symptoms, such as memory problems and changes in appetite.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis (thromboembolic disease), thrombocytopenia, and in some cases, other complications such as memory issues due to microemboli.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms such as depression, memory problems, and decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, thrombocytopenia, and an increased risk of bleeding and thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Hepatic Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease of the liver marked by degeneration of cells, inflammation, and fibrous thickening of tissue. It can lead to thrombocytopenia and an increased risk of bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the blood, leading to thrombocytopenia and an increased risk of thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Kounis Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as allergic angina, a condition where acute coronary syndromes are triggered by an allergic or hypersensitivity reaction. Patients may present with thromboembolic phenomenon.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that can lead to fatigue, depression, and decreased cognitive function due to a lack of adequate iron in the body.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition that can lead to memory problems, depression, and cognitive impairments, as well as anemia which can sometimes be associated with thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Stress
diagnoses.description: While not a medical diagnosis in the strict sense, chronic stress can lead to or exacerbate depression, decrease libido, and indirectly affect memory and concentration.

diagnoses: Neurologic conditions causing cognitive impairment (e.g., Alzheimer's disease)
Diabetes mellitus (uncontrolled leading to weight loss)
Multiple sclerosis (for incontinence and potential neurological symptoms)
Myasthenia gravis (with crisis causing respiratory symptoms)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (due to potential multisystem involvement)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as a cold, it can cause nasal congestion and conjunctival injection due to inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that can cause nasal congestion and sometimes conjunctival injection.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines that can lead to abdominal cramps, hypotension due to dehydration, and in extreme cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause hypotension, abdominal cramps, and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Dysreflexia
diagnoses.description: A condition in individuals with spinal cord injury that can cause hypotension and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough hormones, leading to hypotension and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection, which can lead to hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, which can accompany upper respiratory infections and cause conjunctival injection.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An adverse immune response to a food protein that can cause abdominal cramps and in some severe cases, hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, causing hypotension and potentially leading to incontinence due to weakened physiological responses.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Secondary headache associated with metabolic disorder
Primary headache associated with sexual activity
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Schizophrenia (related to psychosis; must consider in differential if primary diagnosis not explainable by connective tissue disease)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Parvovirus B19)
Lupus Erythematosus with secondary Antiphospholipid Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Microscopic polyangiitis, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Drug Reactions (e.g., Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)
Viral Exanthem due to Epstein-Barr Virus
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Felty's syndrome
Vasculitis Secondary to Infections (e.g., Hepatitis C related cryoglobulinemia)
Drug reactions (e.g., adverse reactions to medications)
Rickettsial Diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)
